greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of permutations tau of {1,...,n} such that k^4 + tau(k)^4 is prime for every k = 1,...,n.
comment: Conjecture: Each term of the sequence is a positive square.
See also A321597 and A321610 for similar conjectures.

This conjecture fails for n = 12. The values of a(12),...,a(20) were first computed by the user MTson on Mathoverflow. Ilya Bogdanov has confirmed that a(n) is indeed a square. See answers and comments to Question 315351 on Mathoverflow. - _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Nov 17 2018
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Primes arising from permutations (II), Question 315341 on Mathoverflow, Nov. 14, 2018.
Zhi-Wei Sun, A mysterious connection between primes and squares, Question 315351 on Mathoverflow, Nov. 15, 2018.
example: a(3) = 1, and (1,3,2) is a permutation of {1,...,n} with 1^4 + 1^4 = 2, 2^4 + 3^4 = 97 and 3^4 + 2^4 = 97 all prime.
program: (PARI) a(n) = matpermanent(matrix(n, n, i, j, ispseudoprime(i^4 + j^4))); \\ _Jinyuan Wang_, Jun 13 2020
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Nov 14 2018
